part of the document, has no styling.

items.name: getTabIndex
items.text: Return the actual tabIndex for this Focusable.
tabIndex attribute value

items.name: getTargetEl
items.text: This is used to determine where to insert the 'html', 'contentEl' and 'items' in this component.

items.name: getTdCls
items.text: Needed for when widget is rendered into a grid cell. The class to add to the cell element.

items.name: getTdType
items.text: Partner method to getTdCls. Returns the base type for the component. Defaults to return `this.xtype`, but All derived classes of Ext.form.field.Text can return the type 'textfield', and all derived classes of Ext.button.Button can return the type 'button'

items.name: getViewRegion
items.text:
Returns the **content** region of this element. That is the region within the borders
and padding.
A Region containing "top, left, bottom, right" member data.

items.name: getWidth
items.text: Gets the current width of the component's underlying element.

items.name: getX
items.text: Gets the current X position of the DOM element based on page coordinates.
The X position of the element

items.name: getXType
items.text: Gets the xtype for this component as registered with Ext.ComponentManager. For a list of all available xtypes, see the Ext.Component header. Example usage: var t = new Ext.form.field.Text(); alert(t.getXType()); // alerts 'textfield'
The xtype

items.name: getXTypes
items.text: Returns this Component's xtype hierarchy as a slash-delimited string. For a list of all available xtypes, see the Ext.Component header. **If using your own subclasses, be aware that a Component must register its own xtype to participate in determination of inherited xtypes.** Example usage: @example var t = new Ext.form.field.Text(); alert(t.getXTypes()); // alerts 'component/field/textfield'
The xtype hierarchy string

items.name: getXY
items.text: Gets the current position of the DOM element based on page coordinates.
The XY position of the element

items.name: getY
items.text: Gets the current Y position of the DOM element based on page coordinates.
The Y position of the element

items.name: hasCls
items.text: Checks if the specified CSS class exists on this element's DOM node.

items.name: className
items.text: The CSS class to check for.
`true` if the class exists, else `false`.

items.name: hasListener
items.text:
Checks to see if this object has any listeners for a specified event, or whether the event bubbles. The answer
indicates whether the event needs firing or not.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to check for
`true` if the event is being listened for or bubbles, else `false`

items.name: hasUICls
items.text: Checks if there is currently a specified uiCls.

items.name: cls
items.text: The cls to check.

items.name: hide
items.text: Hides this Component, setting it to invisible using the configured hideMode.

items.name: animateTarget
items.text: **only valid for cfg-floating Components such as Ext.window.Windows or Ext.tip.ToolTips, or regular Components which have been configured with `floating: true`.**. The target to which the Component should animate while hiding.

items.name: callback
items.text: A callback function to call after the Component is hidden.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the callback is executed.
Defaults to this Component.
this

items.name: initBindable
items.text: This method triggers the lazy configs and must be called when it is time to fully boot up. The configs that must be initialized are: bind, publishes, session, twoWayBindable and viewModel.

items.name: initComponent
initEvents
items.text: Initialize any events on this component

items.name: initFocusableElement
items.text: Sets up the focus listener on this Component's getFocusEl if it has one. Form Components which must implicitly participate in tabbing order usually have a naturally focusable element as their getFocusEl, and it is the DOM event of that receiving focus which drives the Component's onFocus handling, and the DOM event of it being blurred which drives the onBlur handling.

items.name: initFocusableEvents
items.text:
Template method to do any event listener initialization for a Focusable.
This generally happens after the focusEl is available.

items.name: initInheritedState
items.text: Called by getInherited to initialize the inheritedState the first time it is requested.

items.name: initItems
items.text:
This method is called to initialize the `items` collection. A derived class can
override this method to do any last minute manipulation of `items` and then call
this method using `callParent`. Upon return, the `items` will no longer be a simple
array.

items.name: initPadding
items.text:
Initializes padding by applying it to the target element, or if the layout manages
padding ensures that the padding on the target element is "0".

items.name: initRenderData
items.text: Initialized the renderData to be used when rendering the renderTpl.
Object with keys and values that are going to be applied to the renderTpl

items.name: initRenderTpl
items.text: Initializes the renderTpl.
The renderTpl XTemplate instance.

items.name: initState
items.text: Initializes the state of the object upon construction.

items.name: initStyles
items.text:
Applies padding, margin, border, top, left, height, and width configs to the
appropriate elements.

items.name: insert
items.text: Inserts a Component into this Container at a specified index. Fires the beforeadd event before inserting, then fires the event-add event after the Component has been inserted.

items.name: index
items.text:
The index at which the Component will be inserted
into the Container's items collection

items.name: component
items.text: The child Component or config object to insert. Ext uses lazy rendering, and will only render the inserted Component should it become necessary. A Component config object may be passed in order to avoid the overhead of constructing a real Component object if lazy rendering might mean that the inserted Component will not be rendered immediately. To take advantage of this 'lazy instantiation', set the Ext.Component#xtype config property to the registered type of the Component wanted. You can pass an array of Component instances and config objects. For a list of all available xtypes, see Ext.enums.Widget.

component The Component (or config object) that was
inserted with the Container's default config values applied.

items.name: invalidateInheritedState
items.text: This method marks the current inherited state as invalid. The next time a call is made to getInherited the objects will be recreated and initialized.

items.name: is
items.text: Tests whether this Component matches a Ext.ComponentQuery selector string.

items.name: selector
items.text: The selector string to test against.
`true` if this Component matches the selector.

items.name: isAncestor
items.text:
Determines whether **this Component** is an ancestor of the passed Component.
This will return `true` if the passed Component is anywhere within the subtree
beneath this Component.

items.name: possibleDescendant
items.text:
The Component to test for presence
within this Component's subtree.

items.name: isDescendantOf
items.text: Determines whether this component is the descendant of a passed component.

items.name: ancestor
items.text: A Component which may contain this Component.
`true` if the component is the descendant of the passed component, otherwise `false`.

items.name: isDisabled
items.text: Method to determine whether this Component is currently disabled.
the disabled state of this Component.

items.name: isDraggable
items.text: Method to determine whether this Component is draggable.
the draggable state of this component.

items.name: isDroppable
items.text: Method to determine whether this Component is droppable.
the droppable state of this component.

items.name: isFloating
items.text: Method to determine whether this Component is floating.
the floating state of this component.

items.name: isFocusable
items.text: Determine if this Focusable can receive focus at this time. Note that Containers can be non-focusable themselves while delegating focus treatment to a child Component; see Ext.container.Container for more information.

items.name: deep
items.text:
Optionally determine if the container itself
is focusable, or if container's focus is delegated to a child component
and that child is focusable.
True if component is focusable, false if not.

items.name: isHidden
items.text: Method to determine whether this Component is currently set to hidden.
the hidden state of this Component.

items.name: isLayoutChild
items.text:
Checks if this component will be contained by the passed component as part of its
layout run. If `true`, then the layout on `this` can be skipped because it will be
encompassed when the layout for `comp` runs. Typical cases where this may be be `false`
is when asking about floaters nested in containers.

items.name: comp
items.text: The potential owner.
`true` if this component is a layout child of `comp`.

items.name: isLayoutRoot
items.text: Determines whether this Component is the root of a layout. This returns `true` if this component can run its layout without assistance from or impact on its owner. If this component cannot run its layout given these restrictions, `false` is returned and its owner will be considered as the next candidate for the layout root. Setting the _isLayoutRoot property to `true` causes this method to always return `true`. This may be useful when updating a layout of a Container which shrink wraps content, and you know that it will not change size, and so can safely be the topmost participant in the layout run.

items.name: isLayoutSuspended
items.text: Returns `true` if layout is suspended for this component. This can come from direct suspension of this component's layout activity (Ext.Container#suspendLayout) or if one of this component's containers is suspended.
`true` layout of this component is suspended.

items.name: isMasked
items.text: Returns masked state for this Component.

items.name: deep
items.text: True to look up this Component's parent masked state.
True if masked, false otherwise.

items.name: isSuspended
items.text: Checks if all events, or a specific event, is suspended.

items.name: event
items.text: The name of the specific event to check
`true` if events are suspended

items.name: isSyncing
items.text: Checks if a particular binding is synchronizing the value.

items.name: name
items.text: The name of the property being bound to.
`true` if the binding is syncing.

items.name: isVisible
items.text: Returns `true` if this component is visible.

items.name: deep
items.text:
Pass `true` to interrogate the visibility status of all parent Containers to
determine whether this Component is truly visible to the user.

Generally, to determine whether a Component is hidden, the no argument form is needed. For example when creating
dynamically laid out UIs in a hidden Container before showing them.
`true` if this component is visible, `false` otherwise.

items.name: isXType
items.text: Tests whether or not this Component is of a specific xtype. This can test whether this Component is descended from the xtype (default) or whether it is directly of the xtype specified (`shallow = true`). **If using your own subclasses, be aware that a Component must register its own xtype to participate in determination of inherited xtypes.** For a list of all available xtypes, see the Ext.Component header. Example usage: @example var t = new Ext.form.field.Text(); var isText = t.isXType('textfield'); // true var isBoxSubclass = t.isXType('field'); // true, descended from Ext.form.field.Base var isBoxInstance = t.isXType('field', true); // false, not a direct Ext.form.field.Base instance

items.name: xtype
items.text: The xtype to check for this Component

items.name: shallow
items.text:
`true` to check whether this Component is directly of the specified xtype, `false` to
check whether this Component is descended from the xtype.
`true` if this component descends from the specified xtype, `false` otherwise.

items.name: lookup
items.text: Gets a reference to the component with the specified reference value. The method is a short-hand for the lookupReference method.

items.name: key
items.text: The name of the reference to lookup.
The referenced component or null if it is not found.

items.name: lookupComponent
items.text: Called when a raw config object is added to this container either during initialization of the cfg-items config, or when new items are method-add, or method-insert. This method converts the passed object into an instanced child component. This may be overridden in subclasses when special processing needs to be applied to child creation.

items.name: item
items.text: The config object being added.
The component to be added.

items.name: lookupController
items.text:
Gets the controller that controls this view. May be a controller that belongs
to a view higher in the hierarchy.

items.name: skipThis
items.text:
`true` to not consider the controller directly attached
to this view (if it exists).
The controller. null if no controller is found.

items.name: lookupReference
items.text: Gets a reference to the component with the specified reference value. The lookup method is a short-hand version of this method.

items.name: key
items.text: The name of the reference to lookup.
The referenced component or null if it is not found.

items.name: lookupReferenceHolder
items.text: Gets the Controller or Component that is used as the reference holder for this view.

items.name: skipThis
items.text: `false` to return this as the reference holder if this instance has set referenceHolder. Unlike getInheritedConfig this method defaults to `true` because it is possible that a reference property set by the owner of a component that is also a referenceHolder itself. In this case, the reference connects not to this component but to the parent referenceHolder.
The reference holder.

items.name: lookupSession
items.text: Returns the Ext.data.Session for this instance. This property may come from this instance's session or be inherited from this object's parent.

items.name: skipThis
items.text: Pass `true` to ignore a session configured on this instance and only consider an inherited session.

items.name: lookupViewModel
items.text: Returns the Ext.app.ViewModel for this instance. This property may come from this this instance's viewModel or be inherited from this object's parent.

items.name: skipThis
items.text: Pass `true` to ignore a viewModel configured on this instance and only consider an inherited view model.

items.name: makeBindableUpdater
items.text: Returns an update method for the given Config that will call publishState to ensure two-way bindings (via bind) as well as any publishes are updated. This method is cached on the `cfg` instance for re-use.
The updater function.

items.name: mask
items.text: Masks this component with a semi-opaque layer and makes the contents unavailable to clicks. See unmask.

items.name: msg
items.text: A message to show in the center of the mask layer.

items.name: msgCls
items.text: A CSS class name to use on the message element in the center of the layer.

items.name: mon
items.text: Shorthand for addManagedListener.

items.name: move
items.text: Moves a Component within the Container. This method does **not** account for things like splitter components added by a layout. To better handle these situations, it is recommended to use moveBefore or moveAfter instead.

items.name: fromIdx
items.text: The index/component to move.

items.name: toIdx
items.text: The new index for the Component.
component The Component that was moved.

items.name: moveAfter
item
items.text:
The item to move. May be a component,
component configuration object, or an array of either.

items.name: after
items.text: The reference component. May be null.
The moved item(s).

items.name: moveBefore
item
items.text:
The item to move. May be a component,
component configuration object, or an array of either.

items.name: before
items.text: The reference component. May be null.
The moved item(s).

items.name: mun
items.text: Shorthand for removeManagedListener.

items.name: nextChild
items.text:
A method to find a child component after the passed child parameter. If a selector is also provided,
the first child component matching the selector will be returned.

items.name: child
items.text: The child to use as a starting point to find the next child.

items.name: selector
items.text: A Ext.ComponentQuery selector to find the next child. This will return the next child matching this selector. This parameter is optional.
The next child found, null if no child found.

items.name: nextNode
items.text: Returns the next node in the Component tree in tree traversal order. Note that this is not limited to siblings, and if invoked upon a node with no matching siblings, will walk the tree to attempt to find a match. Contrast with nextSibling.

items.name: selector
items.text: A Ext.ComponentQuery selector to filter the following nodes.
The next node (or the next node which matches the selector). Returns null if there is no matching node.

items.name: nextSibling
items.text: Returns the next sibling of this Component. Optionally selects the next sibling which matches the passed Ext.ComponentQuery selector. May also be referred to as **`next()`** Note that this is limited to siblings, and if no siblings of the item match, null is returned. Contrast with nextNode

items.name: selector
items.text: A Ext.ComponentQuery selector to filter the following items.
The next sibling (or the next sibling which matches the selector). Returns null if there is no matching sibling.

items.name: onAdd
items.text:
This method is invoked after a new Component has been added. It
is passed the Component which has been added. This method may
be used to update any internal structure which may depend upon
the state of the child items.

items.name: onAdded
items.text: Method to manage awareness of when components are added to their respective Container, firing an #added event. References are established at add time rather than at render time. Allows addition of behavior when a Component is added to a Container. At this stage, the Component is in the parent Container's collection of child items. After calling the superclass's onAdded, the ownerCt reference will be present, and if configured with a ref, the `refOwner` will be set.

items.name: container
items.text: Container which holds the component.

items.name: pos
items.text: Position at which the component was added.

items.name: instanced
items.text:
`false` if this component was instanced by the parent
container. `true` if the instance already existed when it was passed to the container.

items.name: onAfter
items.text: Appends an after-event handler. Same as Ext.util.Observable#addListener with `order` set to `'after'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to listen for.

items.name: fn
items.text: The method the event invokes.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: An object containing handler configuration.

items.name: onBefore
items.text: Appends a before-event handler. Returning `false` from the handler will stop the event. Same as Ext.util.Observable#addListener with `order` set to `'before'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to listen for.

items.name: fn
items.text: The method the event invokes.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: An object containing handler configuration.

items.name: onBeforeAdd
items.text:
This method is invoked before adding a new child Component. It
is passed the new Component, and may be used to modify the
Component, or prepare the Container in some way. Returning
false aborts the add operation.

items.name: onBoxReady
items.text: Invoked when this component has first achieved size. Occurs after the componentLayout has completed its initial run. This method is not called on components that use liquidLayout, such as Ext.button.Button and Ext.form.field.Base. **Note:** If the Component has a Ext.Component#controller and the controller has a Ext.app.ViewController#boxReady method it will be called passing the Component as the single param.

items.name: width
items.text: The width of this component

items.name: height
items.text: The height of this component

items.name: onDestroy
items.text:
Allows addition of behavior to the destroy operation.
After calling the superclass's onDestroy, the Component will be destroyed.

items.name: onDisable
items.text: Allows addition of behavior to the disable operation. After calling the superclass's onDisable, the Component will be disabled.

items.name: onEnable
items.text: Allows addition of behavior to the enable operation. After calling the superclass's onEnable, the Component will be enabled.

items.name: onFocusEnter
items.text: Called when focus enters this Component's hierarchy

items.name: event
items.text: The underlying DOM event.

items.name: target
items.text: The element gaining focus.

items.name: relatedTarget
items.text: The element losing focus.

items.name: toComponent
items.text: The Component gaining focus.

items.name: fromComponent
items.text: The Component losing focus.

items.name: onFocusLeave
items.text: Called when focus exits from this Component's hierarchy

items.name: event
items.text: The underlying DOM event.

items.name: target
items.text: The element gaining focus.

items.name: relatedTarget
items.text: The element losing focus.

items.name: toComponent
items.text: The Component gaining focus.

items.name: fromComponent
items.text: The Component losing focus.

items.name: onHide
items.text:
Allows addition of behavior to the hide operation. After
calling the superclass's onHide, the Component will be hidden.

Gets passed the same parameters as #hide.

items.name: onInheritedAdd
items.text: Called when this Inheritable is added to a parent

items.name: onInheritedRemove
items.text: Called when this inheritable is removed from a parent

items.name: destroying
items.text: `true` if this item will be destroyed by it's container

items.name: onMouseDown
items.text:
Mousedown brings to front, and programmatically grabs focus
unless the mousedown was on a focusable element

items.name: onPosition
items.text:
Called after the component is moved, this method is empty by default but can be implemented by any
subclass that needs to perform custom logic after a move occurs.

items.name: x
items.text: The new x position.

items.name: y
items.text: The new y position.

items.name: onRemove
items.text:
This method is invoked after a new Component has been
removed. It is passed the Component which has been
removed. This method may be used to update any internal
structure which may depend upon the state of the child items.

items.name: onRender
items.text:
Template method called when this Component's DOM structure is created.

At this point, this Component's (and all descendants') DOM structure *exists* but it has not
been layed out (positioned and sized).

Subclasses which override this to gain access to the structure at render time should
call the parent class's method before attempting to access any child elements of the Component.

items.name: parentNode
items.text: The parent Element in which this Component's encapsulating element is contained.

items.name: containerIdx
items.text: The index within the parent Container's child collection of this Component.

items.name: onResize
items.text: Called when the component is resized. This method is not called on components that use liquidLayout, such as Ext.button.Button and Ext.form.field.Base.

items.name: onScrollEnd
items.text: Invoked when a scroll operation is completed via this component's scrollable.

items.name: x
items.text: The current x position

items.name: y
items.text: The current y position

items.name: onScrollMove
items.text: Invoked when this component is scrolled via its scrollable.

items.name: x
items.text: The current x position

items.name: y
items.text: The current y position

items.name: onScrollStart
items.text: Invoked when a scroll is initiated on this component via its scrollable.

items.name: x
items.text: The current x position

items.name: y
items.text: The current y position

items.name: onShow
items.text:
Allows addition of behavior to the show operation. After
calling the superclass's onShow, the Component will be visible.

Override in subclasses where more complex behaviour is needed.

Gets passed the same parameters as #show.

items.name: onShowComplete
items.text:
Invoked after the #afterShow method is complete.

Gets passed the same `callback` and `scope` parameters that #afterShow received.

items.name: onStateChange
items.text: This method is called when any of the stateEvents are fired.

items.name: owns
items.text: Returns `true` if the passed element is within the container tree of this component. For example if a menu's submenu contains an Ext.form.field.Date, that top level menu owns the elements of the date picker. Using this method, you can tell if an event took place within a certain component tree.

items.name: postBlur
items.text: Template method to do any post-blur processing.

items.name: e
items.text: The event object

items.name: postFocus
items.text: Template method to do any post-focus processing.

items.name: e
items.text: The event object

items.name: prevChild
items.text:
A method to find a child component before the passed child parameter. If a selector is also provided,
the first child component matching the selector will be returned.

items.name: child
items.text: The child to use as a starting point to find the previous child.

items.name: selector
items.text: A Ext.ComponentQuery selector to find the previous child. This will return the first child matching this selector. This parameter is optional.
The previous child found, null if no child found.

items.name: previousNode
items.text: Returns the previous node in the Component tree in tree traversal order. Note that this is not limited to siblings, and if invoked upon a node with no matching siblings, will walk the tree in reverse order to attempt to find a match. Contrast with previousSibling.

items.name: selector
items.text: A Ext.ComponentQuery selector to filter the preceding nodes.
The previous node (or the previous node which matches the selector). Returns null if there is no matching node.

items.name: previousSibling
items.text: Returns the previous sibling of this Component. Optionally selects the previous sibling which matches the passed Ext.ComponentQuery selector. May also be referred to as **`prev()`** Note that this is limited to siblings, and if no siblings of the item match, null is returned. Contrast with previousNode

items.name: selector
items.text: A Ext.ComponentQuery selector to filter the preceding items.
The previous sibling (or the previous sibling which matches the selector). Returns null if there is no matching sibling.

items.name: publishState
items.text: Publish this components state to the `ViewModel`. If no arguments are given (or if this is the first call), the entire state is published. This state is determined by the publishes property. This method is called only by component authors.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property to update.

items.name: value
items.text: The value of `property`. Only needed if `property` is given.

items.name: query
items.text:
Retrieves all descendant components which match the passed selector.
Executes an Ext.ComponentQuery.query using this container as its root.

items.name: selector
items.text:
Selector complying to an Ext.ComponentQuery selector.
If no selector is specified all items will be returned.
Components which matched the selector

items.name: queryBy
items.text:
Retrieves all descendant components which match the passed function.
The function should return false for components that are to be
excluded from the selection.

items.name: fn
items.text:
The matcher function. It will be called with a single argument,
the component being tested.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope in which to run the function. If not specified,
it will default to the active component.
Components matched by the passed function

items.name: queryById
items.text:
Finds a component at any level under this container matching the id/itemId.
This is a shorthand for calling ct.down('#' + id);

items.name: id
items.text: The id to find
The matching id, null if not found

items.name: refreshScroll
items.text:
Implementation which updates the scroll range of a touch scroller.
Subclasses may change implementation.

items.name: registerFloatingItem
items.text: Called by Component#doAutoRender Register a Container configured `floating: true` with this Component's Ext.ZIndexManager. Components added in this way will not participate in any layout, but will be rendered upon first show in the way that Ext.window.Windows are.

items.name: relayEvents
items.text:
Relays selected events from the specified Observable as if the events were fired by `this`.

For example if you are extending Grid, you might decide to forward some events from store.
So you can do this inside your initComponent:

    this.relayEvents(this.getStore(), ['load']);

The grid instance will then have an observable 'load' event which will be passed
the parameters of the store's load event and any function fired with the grid's
load event would have access to the grid using the this keyword (unless the event
is handled by a controller's control/listen event listener in which case 'this'
will be the controller rather than the grid).

items.name: origin
items.text: The Observable whose events this object is to relay.

items.name: events
items.text:
Array of event names to relay or an Object with key/value
pairs translating to ActualEventName/NewEventName respectively. For example:
    this.relayEvents(this, {add:'push', remove:'pop'});

Would now redispatch the add event of this as a push event and the remove event as a pop event.

items.name: prefix
remove
items.text: Removes a component from this container. Fires the beforeremove event before removing, then fires the event-remove event after the component has been removed.

items.name: component
items.text: The component instance or id to remove.

items.name: autoDestroy
items.text: True to automatically invoke the removed Component's Ext.Component#method-destroy function. Defaults to the value of this Container's autoDestroy config.
component The Component that was removed.

items.name: removeAfterListener
items.text: Alias for unAfter.

items.name: removeAll
items.text: Removes all components from this container.

If you expect child items to be sized in response to user interactions, you must configure the Container with a layout manager which creates and manages the type of layout you have in mind. **Omitting the Container's Ext.Container#layout config means that a basic layout manager is used which does nothing but render child components sequentially into the Container. items.name: visitPostOrder
items.text: Traverses the tree rooted at this node in post-order mode, calling the passed function on the nodes at each level. That is the function is called upon each node **after** being called on its children). This method is used at each level down the cascade. Currently Ext.Components and Ext.data.TreeModels are queryable. If you have tree-structured data, you can make your nodes queryable, and use ComponentQuery on them.

items.name: selector
items.text:
A ComponentQuery selector used to filter candidate nodes before calling the function.
An empty string matches any node.

items.name: fn
items.text: The function to call. Return `false` to aborl the traverse.

items.name: node
items.text: The node being visited.

items.name: scope
items.text: The context (`this` reference) in which the function is executed.

items.name: extraArgs
items.text:
A set of arguments to be appended to the function's argument list to pass down extra data known to the caller
**after** the node being visited.

items.name: visitPreOrder
items.text: Traverses the tree rooted at this node in pre-order mode, calling the passed function on the nodes at each level. That is the function is called upon each node **before** being called on its children). This method is used at each level down the cascade. Currently Ext.Components and Ext.data.TreeModels are queryable. If you have tree-structured data, you can make your nodes queryable, and use ComponentQuery on them.

items.name: selector
items.text:
A ComponentQuery selector used to filter candidate nodes before calling the function.
An empty string matches any node.

items.name: fn
items.text: The function to call. Return `false` to aborl the traverse.

items.name: node
items.text: The node being visited.

items.name: scope
items.text: The context (`this` reference) in which the function is executed.

items.name: extraArgs
items.text:
A set of arguments to be appended to the function's argument list to pass down extra data known to the caller
**after** the node being visited.

items.text: Setting this property to `true` causes the isLayoutRoot method to return `true` and stop the search for the top-most component for a layout.

items.name: _renderState
items.text: This property holds one of the following values during the render process: * **0** - The component is not rendered. * **1** - The component has fired beforerender and is about to call beforeRender. The component has just started rendering. * **2** - The component has finished the beforeRender process and is about to call onRender. This is when `rendering` is set to `true`. * **3** - The component has started onRender. This is when rendered is set to `true`. * **4** - The component has finished its afterrender process.

items.name: ariaEl
items.text:
The name of the Component property that holds
a reference to the Element that serves as that Component's ARIA element.
This property will be replaced with the actual Element reference after rendering.

Most of the simple Components will have their main element as ariaEl.

to render into Component's ariaEl. This object is only used during rendering,
and is discarded afterwards.

items.text: `true` indicates an id was auto-generated rather than provided by configuration.

rtl mode it is overridden to convert "l" to "r" and vice versa when required.

items.name: defaultBindProperty
items.text: This property is used to determine the property of a bind config that is just the value. For example, if `defaultBindProperty="value"`, then this shorthand bind config: bind: '{name}' Is equivalent to this object form: bind: { value: '{name}' } The defaultBindProperty is set to "value" for form fields and to "store" for grids and trees.

items.text: Initial suspended call count. Incremented when suspendEvents is called, decremented when resumeEvents is called.

items.name: floatParent
items.text: **Only present for cfg-floating Components which were inserted as child items of Containers.** There are other similar relationships such as the Ext.button.Button which activates a Ext.button.Button#cfg-menu, or the Ext.menu.Item which activated a Ext.menu.Item#cfg-menu, or the Ext.grid.column.Column which activated the column menu. These differences are abstracted away by the up method. Floating Components that are programmatically Ext.Component#method-render will not have a floatParent property. See cfg-floating and zIndexManager

items.name: floating
items.text: The value `true` indicates that this Component is floating.

items.name: floatingItems
items.text: The MixedCollection containing all the floating child items of this container. Will be undefined if there are no floating child items.

items.name: focusEl
items.text:
The component's focusEl.
Available after rendering.

items.name: focusable
items.text: `true` for interactive Components, `false` for static Components. For Containers, this property reflects interactiveness of the Container itself, not its children. See isFocusable. **Note:** Plain components are static, so not focusable.

items.name: frameSize
items.text: Indicates the width of any framing elements which were added within the encapsulating element to provide graphical, rounded borders. See the frame config. This property is null if the component is not framed. This is an object containing the frame width in pixels for all four sides of the Component containing the following properties:

items.name: top
items.text: The width of the top framing element in pixels.

items.name: right
items.text: The width of the right framing element in pixels.

items.name: bottom
items.text: The width of the bottom framing element in pixels.

items.name: left
items.text: The width of the left framing element in pixels.

items.name: width
items.text: The total width of the left and right framing elements in pixels.

items.name: height
items.text: The total height of the top and right bottom elements in pixels.

items.name: hasFocus
items.text: `true` if this component has focus.

items.name: hasListeners
items.text: This object holds a key for any event that has a listener. The listener may be set directly on the instance, or on its class or a super class (via observe) or on the Ext.app.EventBus. The values of this object are truthy (a non-zero number) and falsy (0 or undefined). They do not represent an exact count of listeners. The value for an event is truthy if the event must be fired and is falsy if there is no need to fire the event. The intended use of this property is to avoid the expense of fireEvent calls when there are no listeners. This can be particularly helpful when one would otherwise have to call fireEvent hundreds or thousands of times. It is used like this: if (this.hasListeners.foo) { this.fireEvent('foo', this, arg1); }

items.name: initFocusable
items.text:
Template method to do any Focusable related initialization that
does not involve event listeners creation.

items.name: initialConfig
items.text: The config object passed to the constructor during Component creation.

items.name: isComponent
items.text: `true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Component, or subclass thereof.

items.name: isContainer
items.text: `true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Container, or subclass thereof.

items.name: isObservable
items.text: `true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Observable, or subclass thereof.

items.name: items
items.text: The Collection containing all the child items of this container.

items.name: layoutCounter
items.text: The number of container layout calls made on this object.

items.name: maskOnDisable
items.text:
This is an internal flag that you use when creating custom components. By default this is set to `true` which means
that every component gets a mask when it's disabled. Components like FieldContainer, FieldSet, Field, Button, Tab
override this property to `false` since they want to implement custom disable logic.

items.name: ownerCt
items.text: This Component's owner Ext.container.Container (is set automatically when this Component is added to a Container). *Important.* This is not a universal upwards navigation pointer. It indicates the Container which owns and manages this Component if any. There are other similar relationships such as the Ext.button.Button which activates a Ext.button.Button#cfg-menu, or the Ext.menu.Item which activated a Ext.menu.Item#cfg-menu, or the Ext.grid.column.Column which activated the column menu. These differences are abstracted away by the up method. **Note**: to access items within the Container see itemId.

items.name: rendered
items.text: Indicates whether or not the component has been rendered.

items.name: scrollFlags
items.text: An object property which provides unified information as to which dimensions are scrollable based upon the scrollable settings (And for *views* of trees and grids, the owning panel's Ext.panel.Table#scroll setting). Note that if you set overflow styles using the style config or Ext.panel.Panel#bodyStyle config, this object does not include that information. Use scrollable if you need to access these flags. This object has the following properties:

items.name: x
items.text:
`true` if this Component is scrollable
horizontally - style setting may be `'auto'` or `'scroll'`.

items.name: y
items.text:
`true` if this Component is scrollable
vertically - style setting may be `'auto'` or `'scroll'`.

items.name: both
items.text:
`true` if this Component is scrollable both
horizontally and vertically.

items.name: overflowX
items.text:
The `overflow-x` style setting, `'auto'`
or `'scroll'` or `''`.

items.name: overflowY
items.text:
The `overflow-y` style setting, `'auto'`
or `'scroll'` or `''`.

items.name: synthetic
items.text: This property is `true` if the component was created internally by the framework and is not explicitly user-defined. This is set for such things as `Splitter` instances managed by border and `box` layouts.

items.name: validRefRe
items.text: Regular expression used for validating reference values.

items.name: zIndexManager
items.text: Only present for Ext.Component#cfg-floating Components after they have been rendered. A reference to the ZIndexManager which is managing this Component's z-index. The Ext.ZIndexManager maintains a stack of floating Component z-indices, and also provides a single modal mask which is insert just beneath the topmost visible modal floating Component. Floating Components may be Ext.Component#toFront or Ext.Component#toBack of the z-index stack. This defaults to the global Ext.WindowManager for floating Components that are programatically Ext.Component#method-render. For Ext.Component#cfg-floating Components that are added to a Container, the ZIndexManager is acquired from the first ancestor Container found that is floating. If no floating ancestor is found, the global Ext.WindowManager is used. See Ext.Component#cfg-floating and zIndexParent

items.name: zIndexParent
items.text: Only present for Ext.Component#cfg-floating Components which were inserted as child items of Containers, and which have a floating Container in their containment ancestry. For Ext.Component#cfg-floating Components which are child items of a Container, the zIndexParent will be a floating ancestor Container which is responsible for the base z-index value of all its floating descendants. It provides a Ext.ZIndexManager which provides z-indexing services for all its descendant floating Components. Floating Components that are programmatically Ext.Component#method-render will not have a zIndexParent property. For example, the dropdown Ext.view.BoundList of a ComboBox which is in a Window will have the Window as its zIndexParent, and will always show above that Window, wherever the Window is placed in the z-index stack. See Ext.Component#cfg-floating and zIndexManager

items.name: $scroll-indicator-background-color
items.text: The background color of scroll indicators when touch scrolling is enabled

items.name: $scroll-indicator-border-radius
items.text: The border-radius of scroll indicators when touch scrolling is enabled

items.name: $scroll-indicator-margin
items.text: The space between scroll indicators and the edge of their container

items.name: $scroll-indicator-opacity
items.text: The opacity of scroll indicators when touch scrolling is enabled

items.name: $scroll-indicator-size
items.text: The background color of scroll indicators when touch scrolling is enabled
